posts.html:
BuildPlane is the next step in project management for commercial construction.

In discussions with our friends in construction, we learned that current software tools were either outdated and difficult to use efficiently, or modern but overly complex for a common workflow across the industry. We're solving that with a focused and lightweight set of tools that allow project managers to spend less time in front of their laptops and mobile devices and more time with their people and on the job site.

Using BuildPlane is easy. For example, when you view your projects on your dashboard, you'll see your daily financial updates as well as high-priority to-do items. At a glance, you can check the status of—or kick off—new project actions like:

  • Subcontract management
  • Requests for quotes/requests for pricing
  • Document requests and management
  • Change order management

Automation

As lightweight as it is, BuildPlane is also robust, smoothly handling such functions as automating repetitive tasks. For example, BuildPlane automatically requests and collects pay apps from subcontractors at set intervals, alerting you when they arrive. You need software that works for you even when you aren't working.

Why BuildPlane?

We use software as a medium to solve real problems in ways that empower our customers to do even more with their skills. We aren't interested in you being an expert in our software, but in you, using our software, discovering new ways to delight your project owners and drive better margins and results for your business. You got into construction to build the world, not work a desk.

We want BuildPlane to connect you, the project managers who are our customers, to the industry and the people that you love. We'll do everything we can to put a smile on your face.

About the team

Each of the founding team members has 20 years of experience building software (60 cumulative years). During that time, we’ve designed, built, and supported software for open source cloud databases (Compose, acquired by IBM), YMCA operations management (Daxko), and university retention outreach (GradesFirst, acquired by EAB).  Ben and Jason were founders at Compose, and all 3 worked together at GradesFirst.

About Jason
Hello, I am Jason. I live in Birmingham, AL, with my wife and our 5 children. When I decided to work on BuildPlane, it was because I saw a real opportunity to make a difference in the lives of construction professionals. I've always had a heart for solving tough problems. For fun, I enjoy being on the water with my kids and exploring the expanding food and beer scene in Birmingham.

About Ben
Hey, I am Ben. My wife and I have lived in Birmingham since I graduated from Auburn University. Besides navigating life with 3 kids, I have been building the engineering teams for many successful startups for the past 15 years. We started to focus on the problems facing commercial construction after being personally involved in the construction space and seeing needs not being met for so many PMs and subcontractors. When I am not writing software I am typically on the lake with family pulling kids around behind the boat or enjoying a lazy day on the water.

About Chris
Hey, I’m Chris, a founder of BuildPlane. I’m a husband and a father of 2. When I told my wife about the idea to do another startup, she said, “Good, go. You are happier when you are all in on an idea.” She refuses to let me work from the house—if I’m at home, I’m Dad. When I’m not working on BuildPlane, I’m outside riding bicycles (mountain and road), floating in a canoe on the Cahaba River, fishing, hunting, playing ultimate Frisbee, throwing a lacrosse ball with my son, water-skiing, or shooting sporting clays.

posts.html:
We're introducing ourselves with a series of blog posts about BuildPlane features that make your life easier. We'll begin with the starting point for any project: the Project Dashboard.

When you click on "Projects" at the top of the page and then on the name of a specific project in your list, you'll get the project dashboard. The dashboard gives you an up-to-the-minute look at where you stand. Any single project has a list of to-dos a mile long, so we show you at a glance the information your team needs today.

High-level financials

Commercial construction lives and dies by project financials. You'll see the high-level financials down the left side of the dashboard. They show the official standings of where your project started and where it is now. The committed costs include Change Orders that have been signed and executed with your owner and subs.

Change Orders

To keep work moving, you may accept the handshake of a subcontractor making a change, but you also want to move that change through official channels to ensure that it gets paid.

Until a change is finalized, it's always fluid. BuildPlane tracks your change orders according to exposure and approval status. Once you know about a potential change, get it in the system, and the dashboard will make sure it does not get lost.

Startup Documents, issues, tasks, Closeout Documents

The dashboard lets you track all the Startup/Closeout Documents, issues, and tasks for all of your subcontractors in the same place you track your financials. Nothing stalls a jobsite like paperwork, so we help you make sure your paperwork is in place.

We've designed the dashboard to be intuitive. Once you start working with it, you'll quickly be able to navigate it without a second thought, just like you do your phone.

We'll walk through each of your workflows in more detail in a series of follow-up blog posts. Coming next: the Subcontractor Portal.

posts.html:
Startup Documents are the checklist that subcontractors have to complete before they can hit the jobsite. For Project Managers, clicking or tapping the Startup Docs tab on the left side of the Project Dashboard brings up a list of all Startup Documents.

To make managing the workflow as intuitive as possible, we also present Startup Document information in other places—for example, a list of Urgent Startup Documents. Let's look at several aspects of handling Startup Documents:

  • The Startup Documents flow
  • The Urgent Startup Documents report
  • Document coordination
  • Subcontractors
  • Flexibility

Startup Documents flow

A single startup flow is simple: 1) request information from a subcontractor; 2) receive information from the subcontractor; 3) store information from the subcontractor.

If you had only one flow to worry about, keeping track would be easy. The complexity comes from handling potentially hundreds of Startup Document flows at once. We break down that complexity in several ways.

Urgent Startup Documents report

Project Managers can click or tap the Reports tab at the top of the Project Dashboard, then click/tap Urgent Startup Documents. You'll see all documents required or expiring in the next 3 weeks. It's that simple, but it's a powerful report. It shows documents across all projects that the currently authenticated user is assigned:

Clicking on one of the links at the left takes you to the corresponding document management for that subcontract.

Document coordination

Clicking on a particular subcontract (in this scenario, we clicked on 20840-012) displays documents that have been approved, documents that are waiting to be approved, and documents that have expired.

By clicking "Send Document Request," PMs can fire off an email to the Subcontractor requesting that they update their documents.

Subcontractors

Subcontractors have a separate portal into their own world. In the Subcontractor Portal, a Startup Documents Requests tab makes it easy to stay on top of all requests. Here's how a document request from a General Contractor looks:

Flexibility

Since different companies work in different ways, we give you a variety of options for consuming Startup Documents. Here's how it looks when a PM clicks the Startup Docs tab at the left on the Project Dashboard:

You can also, for example, click the Reports tab, also at the left on the dashboard (not the other Reports tab at the top of the page), and then Startup Docs: Received/Approved Log for an at-a-glance look at the status of all Startup Documents. Explore the dashboard, try the options, and see which one(s) you like.

The Subcontractor Portal prioritizes the needs of the Subcontractor. As soon as you log in, you see "Action Needed" alerts at the top of the page reminding you of anything that requires immediate attention.

The portal lists all projects for which you're a Subcontractor. Through it, you and the GC can send back and forth the information you both need.

Subcontract project detail

When you click or tap on a project name, you will find information on:

  • Project Documents
  • Pay Apps
  • RFPs (Requests for Pricing)
  • Startup Document Requests
  • Closeout Document Requests

Your Pay Apps

You can track your submitted pay apps through the entire process. You'll no longer wonder whether the information made it through. You'll see directly from your portal:

Your RFPs (Requests for Pricing)

When you get those Requests for Pricing in an email, you never know if they make it back to the GC. Through your portal, you can see the delivery with certainty:

Get started today

We designed the BuildPlane Subcontractor Portal to streamline your paperwork so you can concentrate on your real work. To get started today, sign up or request a demo.

posts.html:
You're a Project Manager, and you've just gotten a call from an owner/architect asking you to price out a change. Now you need to get responses from your subcontractors.

With BuildPlane, that's simple:

  1. You create an RFP.
  2. BuildPlane automates emails.
  3. You receive responses through Subcontractor Portals.
  4. You roll up the information.

Create an RFP

Every project has an RFPs tab on the menu at the left of the Project Dashboard. (To get to the dashboard, click or tap the Projects tab at the top of the page, then click/tap the name of the project you want.)

When you click on the RFPs tab, you'll see all the RFPs for a project:

When you click on "Create a New RFP" in the green box at the top right of the RFP list, you get 2 tools that make the task easy:

  1. On the left, boxes to fill in with information about the RFP.
  2. On the right, a list of your subcontractors on the project, so you can quickly set up an email list for the RFP simply by clicking checkboxes.

BuildPlane automates emails

Once you fill in the necessary information and set up your email list, just click "Email RFP to Selected Subcontractors" at the bottom of the screen. BuildPlane then emails all the subcontractors you picked. Here's what the email sent to the subcontractors looks like:

Receive Responses

When the Subcontactor opens their Subcontract Portal, they will see an "Action Needed" alert and be able to respond directly from the portal:

The sub sees all the information they need. When they click on the RFP number, they get a form that makes it quick and simple to submit a response:

Roll up information

As subcontractors submit, you'll see the responses come in:

Every step of the way, we've tried to make it as easy as possible to gather RFP responses from your subcontractors so you can keep the job moving smoothly.

posts.html:
Managing subcontracts is the key to staying on schedule and on budget with commercial construction. The big-picture concerns with subcontracts on a project are:

  • Financials
  • Workflows
  • Contact information

Financials

When viewing the list of subcontracts on a project and then viewing each subcontract, you will see financial information up front. Once you log in to BuildPlane and click or tap on a project name, you'll reach your Project Dashboard. Click/tap on the Subcontracts tab at left, and you'll see the Subcontractor Dashboard:

From the Subcontractor Dashboard, you can see the total changes for all subcontracts on the project. You can easily find the sources of exposures and client costs.

When you click on the number of a subcontract, you'll see additional financial information:

This is the dashboard for a single subcontract. Across the top you'll see:

  • Original Amount: The cost of the original subcontract.
  • Approved Change Orders: Total amount in dollars of sub change orders that have been approved for this subcontractor.
  • Committed Cost: The new subcontract cost, including approved change orders, plus the percentage increase in committed cost as a result of the change orders.
  • Actual Remaining: When you use BuildPlane's Pay Apps, we track the remaining amount to be paid for the subcontract.
  • Startup Docs: The number of documents received/requested for this subcontract.

Workflows

Directly below that information, you'll see a horizontal row of tabs. Clicking on them can show you the following:

Potential Change Items: Sub costs that have not yet been assigned to a sub change order—typically site work.

Change Orders: Sub change orders, including those that are being assembled and tracked for approval.

Pay Apps: The Pay Apps that have been requested for the subcontract.

Startup Docs: The documents required for the subcontractor to be on-site.

People: A list of people on the subcontract.

Notes: A list of notes that you are keeping about the subcontract.

Contact information

Under the People tab, you can store the email and phone/text contact information for everyone involved with the subcontract. A simple system of checkboxes lets you manage who gets contacted about what aspect(s) of the subcontract: Financials, Pay App Requests, RFPs, Startup Documents, and Closeout Documents.

To email any of the contacts, just click their email address. That opens a blank, preaddressed email form ready for you to fill out.

At first glance, all of this may seem like a lot to take in. But we put a lot of thought (and trial and error) into making the Subcontractor Dashboard as intuitive as possible and giving you quick, easy access to the information you need.

Once you start using BuildPlane, you'll soon be navigating it instinctively, just the way you do your smartphone.

posts.html:
No one tells Project Managers this, but they are effectively the Chief Financial Officers (CFOs) on their projects.

Finance isn't accounting. Accounting deals with certainties, which is why accounting systems rarely work for building construction jobsites. Finance is about projecting future financial outcomes by tracking expected revenue, known costs, potential costs, and future expenses. This is the primary job of project managers because all workflows lead back to financials.

An additional problem is that commercial construction follows a nonlinear path. Changes can originate with both owners and subcontractors. Owners' changes become costs out to subcontractors. Subcontractor changes have to be tracked to be billed back to the owner or tracked as an exposure.

Change Orders have to be tracked for exposure and certainty as well. For each project, BuildPlane puts Change Order updates right in the middle of the Project Dashboard for each project:

Change Order financial widgets

In the middle column, you'll see Change Order widgets for Sub Change Orders and Owner Change Orders. Each widget follows a similar pattern:

Numbers across the top of the widget represent the count of the changes in each category. They are listed from most certain on the left to least certain on the right. As projects move closer to the end, there should be fewer and fewer "Potential Change Items" and "Pending" items. They should move to "Approved" and, for owner changes, "Executed."

Each widget also lists the dollar amounts of the changes, with the most certain numbers at the top and the least certain at the bottom. Again, you want everything to migrate up from "Potential" to "Committed" or "Executed."

These simple but powerful widgets deliver a real-time, easy-to-understand snapshot of project status. After all, as a CFO, you always need to be on top of the numbers.

posts.html:
In our conversations with Project Managers at GCs and Subcontractors, we've learned that the hardest thing is communicating information. It's difficult enough making sure you're talking to the right person on the phone or copying the right person on an email. Technical systems, like the BuildPlane app, can add extra uncertainty: does the right person have access?

Now, a Project Manager can give a Subcontractor the ability to manage access on their own, without having to clear everything through the PM. When adding a user to a subcontract, the PM should check "Manage Subcontract Users and Permissions":

On the subcontract page, that user will see "Manage Permissions":

After clicking into "Manage Permissions," the subcontractor can give permissions to individuals:

Or, by clicking the green "Add User" button, they can add necessary team members to the subcontract:

This is one of those simple but powerful features that empowers both Subcontractors and Project Managers to get information in the hands of the right people. posts.html:
We've launched the ability for Project Managers to review and approve Payment Applications sent by Subcontractors on their projects.

BuildPlane already makes it simple to request timely and accurate Pay Apps from your subcontractors.  However, there are moments where you, as a Project Manager, clearly see an inaccuracy or may have questions about the figures sent over by the Subcontractor.

Now, when reviewing a submitted Pay App, you can either approve it, or reject it, asking the Subcontractor for additional information or correction. BuildPlane saves you the time, hassle, and disruption of sending a separate email or text or having to make a phone call. We make all of this easy for the Subcontractor to understand, showing them updated status and sending them notifications.

Let's see how it works!

Viewing submitted Pay Apps

BuildPlane has two ways to view Payment Applications: grouped by month or grouped by Subcontract. This allows you, as the Project Manager, to see all the Payment Applications for a project or a more focused list of the Pay Apps for a single Subcontractor.

View: All the Subcontractor Pay Apps for a Month

View: All the Pay Apps (for a Subcontractor) for a Project

Viewing a Submitted Pay App

Once you select the Pay App submission to review, you'll be presented with the following screen. It presents you with the most important information first, the option to approve or reject the Pay App, as well as historical financial data for this Subcontractor and their work on the project.

In the top left, you'll see the information about this Pay App request. This is a snapshot of the most recent Pay App submitted.

To the right, you'll see the Pay App status, with options to approve or reject.  One a status is provided, it will be displayed to anyone that views this Pay App submission.

At the bottom, BuildPlane displays Historical Information. You'll see the Subcontractor Pay App History for the subcontract as well as the Subcontract Cash Flow. This is a great way to visually remember how change orders may have impacted the numbers your Subcontractor submitted for your review.

What happens when you approve or reject?

When a Pay App is approved, it will "lock in" the status to the Pay App and BuildPlane will communicate to the Subcontractor that all is in order. Anyone else on your project that views the Pay App will see who approved it and the date that it was approved.

When a Pay App is rejected, BuildPlane sends notice to the Subcontractor that the Pay App, in current form, is not accepted. Also, we'll include any comments that you added. After that, BuildPlane provides the Subcontractor with a simple way to submit a revision to the Project Manager. From there, the review process starts again.

BuildPlane's goal is to make the communication and sharing of information between the General Contractor and the Subcontractor fast and easy.

More updates coming

We have new features in the works that will connect additional people to the pay applications workflow, like accountants.  If you have any questions, please reach out to us at support@buildplane.com. We'd enjoy the opportunity to get to know you!

posts.html:
The next wave of construction software will win with usability. Most existing construction software focuses on information inputs and outputs without much regard for how much pain someone using the software endures.  With constructions' current set of software tools, the #1 competitor for any construction software is Excel and e-mail and a printer. Why? Because Excel is fast and flexible, e-mail is obvious, and printed paper never has downtime.

BuildPlane equally weights information flows and usability.  We are focusing on reducing the effort required to transmit data between parties.

It's not only about PMs or architects or subcontractors

Software in the current market focuses on one person in the construction information process. It is built specifically for the PM or architect or subcontractor. Anyone who is not the specified user gets a subpar experience that is frankly awful.  Architect software confounds PMs trying to provide simple responses, as does PM software for subcontractors.

Our team has a better way. BuildPlane's software philosophy is one where each member of the construction process has their experience tailored to their needs. A project manager's view is specific to their need for financial status and document flows.  A subcontractor's view is built around seeing their requests and responses.

BuildPlane sells directly to construction Project Managers (not the CTO or operations folks). We recognize that improving the experience for subs and architects also improves the PM's experience. That is why our team invests in the wholistic information flow.

To learn more, signup for BuildPlane, or reach out to me at chris@buildplane.com.

posts.title: BuildPlane Submittals is Live
posts.html:
Today, our team is launching our BuildPlane Submittals – a fast and easy way to: upload and read a spec book, create a Submittal Log, track responses from subcontractors and the design team, and print or export the latest information for OAC meetings.

BuildPlane Submittals vs. Excel

Our goal with BuildPlane Submittals is that project managers will not want to use an an Excel spreadsheet again for submittals. This is an optimistic goal, given that spreadsheets are powering the industry. And, we think our team accomplished it.

But, why would we try to replace spreadsheets? We'll get to that later.

Software needs to actually reduce workload

Last January, we launched BuildPlane with the goal of improving the lives of construction project managers through improved information and communications tools. In short, we wanted to reduce stress and the 50-70+ hour work weeks that plague them.

Since then, we've joined along side many construction project managers, studying and understanding their construction data flows. Consistently, project managers asked if we could help ease the burden of Submittals as well. Today, after working with a few of these project managers to test the beta, we are launching BuildPlane Submittals for everyone.

Why BuildPlane Submittals is better

When building submittals, we focused on two things we've kept hearing from construction PMs: Lightweight & Fast. This, ultimately, is why spreadsheets are a popular go-to. Despite their clear drawbacks and, spreadsheets are addictive because they are lightweight and fast.

So, we wanted to provide both: a lightweight and fast approach to Submittals, but with all the tracking, auditing, and communication you need to control the process from initial requests to in-the-field implementation.

We're proud of this release and in our committment to improving the communication and document flow between GCs, Subcontractors, and Design teams. Sign up and try out BuildPlane Submittals today!

Or: Learn more about BuildPlane Submittals.

posts.html:
If you're looking for a simple way to add more fun and engagement to interactions with new (or existing) customers, upgrade your transactional emails with emoji. 💪

Not only can this improve the personality and "look" of your customer communications, but it can also increase their effectiveness and performance, giving your customers a more friendly and positive view of your company. It's simple!

Ok, so what are Emoji?

Hey, fair question. Emoji are ubiquitous today but are often seen more in text than email. The simplest explanation: emoji are tiny illustrations that can be used to demonstrate facial expressions or common objects.

The common objects that emoji can represent are excellent at giving users visual cues when they quickly scan text. Seeing a familiar illustration provides a reference point, allowing the user to dive in at that spot and pay closer attention to the text they're interested in.

Plus, the emoji can serve as a visual anchor, giving the user a simple way to return to a specific point in a sea of words.

Additionally, emoji facial expressions can add emotion and tone to a conversation. We all tend to inject tone into text in different ways. Emoji can help to frame emotion and provide clarity to a section of text.

Now that we're all set with what they are, here are a few helpful tips you can use to make a real impact:

Tip #1: Use Emoji to Draw Attention to Text ✍️

Is there an area of the text you want to highlight? A word you want to make certain lands with your users? That's a great spot to add emoji.

Tip #2: Add Value to your Users 💰

Sure, you want to get your message across. Who doesn't? However, think about how using an illustration would improve the clarity of your message, helping your user find the information they want more quickly and ensure the accuracy of their next steps.

You are responsible for your user's success, and by valuing them, you can ensure they find it with your message.

Tip #3: Don't Use Too Many 🙅

Sure, sprinkling emoji into your copy is fun, but let's not get carried away. There's a balance, and you should view emoji as an excellent way to add seasoning to your text. You'll know best for your audience, but remember the adage that "too much" salt ruins the dish.

Tip #4: Don't Be Alarmist 🔥

Many emoji convey warnings, loud noises, emergencies, etc. Be careful about the use of these. Similar to using all caps in words, they can increase anxiety in your readers and cause mental strain.

Tip #5: We're all Learning, Therefore Experiment 🔬

Don't fear getting it right the first time. Try something. Measure. Adjust. Repeat. Know that it will take you and your team some time to fine-tune your message.

Emoji are a simple and creative way to improve how you communicate with your users. Added in the right way, they can enhance the clarity of your message and increase engagement in normally (somewhat) boring and rote transactional emails. Your users are worth it! 🥰

posts.html:
Emails can be so boring. Sometimes they're not engaging or creative at all, which really ruins that initial excitement when something new pops in your inbox.

Every message that comes from your company is an extension of your brand. You wouldn't skimp on the creativity of your marketing campaigns, so why would you in your transactional emails?

That's why it's so important to optimize transactional emails. After all, these are the messages that people are often waiting for - whether it's a confirmation of an order or a password reset request. If these emails are poorly designed and lack personality, they're likely to disappoint. However, if they're well-crafted and engaging, they can provide a real boost to customer satisfaction.

Consistency is Key

Have you ever bought something online and then received a confirmation email that looked like it was written by a completely different company? It's confusing, right? You might assume it’s just a scam. This is why consistency is important in transactional emails. You want your customers to have a good impression of your company, and using the same template for different things will help you show your customers that you are legitimate.

Creating Cohesion

The inbox is a crowded place. You have to be able to stand out. Creating a cohesive look that is immediately recognizable as being from your company is one of the best ways to do that. One of the most important things to remember is to use the same color schemes throughout your email. Another quick way is to use the same logo that is on your website and other marketing materials.

Less is More

You don't want to use a lot of fancy fonts or decorations that will make it hard for your customers to read the email. After all, the whole point of a transactional email is to convey information clearly and concisely. Stick with simple, easy-to-read fonts so your customers can understand the message you're trying to send.

The Trick to the Layout

You want it to be easy to read, but you don’t want to look like you’re skimping on design. The trick is to find a happy medium between these two extremes. A simple design is usually the best way to go. Too much clutter is confusing and looks unprofessional. Keep it clean and keep it simple.

Get Your Customers to Take Action

Crafting an effective Call to Action is not always easy. One of the most important things to keep in mind is that your CTA should be clear and prominent. It should be easy for the recipient to see and understand, without getting lost in the rest of the email. It's helpful to use strong language and make the CTA stand out visually. By having an effective CTA, you can increase the chances that your recipients will take action.

Test Out Different Options

So how do you choose the right design for your needs? The best way is to test out a few different designs and see which one gets the best results. Try different layout, colors, and images to see what works best for your audience. And don't be afraid to experiment! After all, the only way to find out what works is to try it out.

In order to make transactional emails more effective, it is important to design them in a way that encourages engagement. This can be done by using clear and concise text, making use of easily visible buttons and links, and testing different designs until you find what works best for your audience. Create transactional emails that are not only more effective but also more pleasing to look at. Have you tried any of these techniques when designing your own transactional emails?

posts.html:
Enveloop is a developer-focused message builder and API that makes it easy to design & send beautiful emails and texts from your app using one simple implementation. You can sign up for free at: https://app.enveloop.com.

Simply put – Much effort is put into improving and optimizing marketing-style emails, but transactional emails are often written in code and never revisited. Ultimately, this degrades your user experience. Let's do better!

In this article, we're focused on subject lines.

Subject lines for your emails are like a news headline – they must grab your attention in a sea of noise. Too, they need to convey important information in a useful way. It's a tricky balance.

Recently, we registered my oldest child for an "Engineering Day" at one of his prospective universities. Afterward, we received an email from the university. The subject line read:

E-Day Registration Submitted

Generic – but sure, there's some useful information there. We can be somewhat confident that our registration was received. This is typical of a transactional email subject line: You did something. We got the thing you did. Good job.

Still, there are ways we can improve this experience and value our users more. Here are a few simple & actionable steps this school could take to make this subject line more useful and engaging.

For this illustration, we'll name our school: Green University. Let's do this.

Tip #1: Make it Clear

Craft a clear and concise subject line that immediately tells the recipient who the email is from and what it's about.

So, I agree with you that the above subject line is concise. Yet, it's not clear who it's from. Instead of:

E-Day Registration Submitted

We could make the subject line more clear (and reinforce our branding 😉).

Green University: E-Day Registration Submitted

Remember, people may not remember the specific name of an event or the name of a tool, but they can more easily remember broader concepts, locations, etc. Give your users anchors to call back on.

Tip #2: Use Good Action Verbs

This tip sounds so simple – well, because it is. ☺️ Yet, it helps tremendously.

Remember, even though you are writing a transactional email, you should treat it as an interaction between two individuals – it doesn't matter if you are inviting, adding, removing, registering, notifying, etc. – make the user feel like they are working with another person, not an app.

Instead of:

Green University: E-Day Registration Submitted

Let's change it to:

Green University: E-Day Registration Received!

Again, it's simple. But, it removes a technical word like "submitted" and tells the user what actually happened – Green University received all the information I just sent them, registering my child for "E-Day". "Submitted" sounds like I jettisoned all my information into the ether, hoping it found the right spot to land. 🪐

Tip #3: Make it Personal

Sure, subject lines have to be brief – but you still have room to make it about the user. Let's take a look at the changes we've made so far:

Green University: E-Day Registration Received!

In this example, though, I registered my teenager for this event. I took the action, but it wasn't about me. Also, I may have other children – and they may have other activities. Let's value our users and give them helpful data.

This is pretty good:

Green University: E-Day Registration Received!

However, let's go this direction:

Green University: Hayden's E-Day Registration Received!

Or ... maybe these options:

Green University: Hayden's successfully registered for E-Day!
Green University: E-Day Registration Received - Hayden Williams

There are a few other variants you could include as well (perhaps tying closely to your company's branding). Adding useful personal information makes the subject line inviting and the experience positive/engaging.

Tip #4: Use Keywords

Transactional emails are vital. However, the (obvious) reality is that people get high quantities of email – daily. A person's inbox is noisy. Therefore, using keywords in your subject lines are like useful titles in a web search.

  • Keywords make it easier to scan for important anchor data.
  • Keywords make searching, in the user's mail client, more successful.
  • Keywords improve the user experience by making information easier to obtain.

That said, here's our current subject line:

Green University: Hayden's E-Day Registration Received!

This has some keywords already. "Green University", "Hayden", and "E-Day". So, we're mostly in good shape. Given it's a registration confirmation email, we could include the date of the event. This makes user scanning more fruitful.

Consider this version:

Green University: Hayden is registered for E-Day - Mar 15, 2023! 🌟

In this, we have keywords, useful information for our user's eyes to scan across, and it's a quick reminder of the date of the event. Plus, we have a bit of a friendly, but not-over-the-top flourish at the end to add a bit of fun.

Success!

Okay – let's take a moment to see what we have accomplished.

Original Subject Line:

E-Day Registration Submitted

Optimized Subject Line:

Green University: Hayden is registered for E-Day - Mar 15, 2023! 🌟

Nice! 😍

These small changes took 5 minutes and, as a developer, the dynamic/personalized content is straight-forward to implement (especially if you are using Enveloop!). Your end user will appreciate the effort.

Use Enveloop 😎

With Enveloop, you can easily make and test optimizations like this without having to re-deploy your application. Getting subject lines out of your code and into the hands of your team is a simple/powerful way to empower your team to make your communication compliment your company, application, and brand!

A Couple of Reminders

  • Avoid excessive punctuation. It can trigger SPAM filters unexpectedly and doesn't benefit the user.
  • Convey appreciation to you users. Reading email is taking their time – value that time you have with them and they will think more positively about you and your brand.
  • Keep your subject lines as short as possible, but not too short.
  • Subject lines are visual anchors to important information. You want your users to find your email and read what's inside. That empowers them and reduces your support load.

Subject lines ... small, but important! Make these improvements and your users will be more successful!

In this, we have keywords, useful information for our user's eyes to scan across, and it's a quick reminder of the date of the event. Plus, we have a bit of a friendly, but not-over-the-top flourish at the end to add a bit of fun.

E-Day Registration Submitted

Green University: Hayden is registered for E-Day - Mar 15, 2023! 🌟

Nice! 😍

These small changes took 5 minutes and, as a developer, the dynamic/personalized content is straight-forward to implement (especially if you are using Enveloop!). Your end user will appreciate the effort.

With Enveloop, you can easily make and test optimizations like this without having to re-deploy your application. Getting subject lines out of your code and into the hands of your team is a simple/powerful way to empower your team to make your communication compliment your company, application, and brand!

 * Avoid excessive punctuation. It can trigger SPAM filters unexpectedly and doesn't benefit the user.
 * Convey appreciation to you users. Reading email is taking their time – value that time you have with them and they will think more positively about you and your brand.
 * Keep your subject lines as short as possible, but not too short.
 * Subject lines are visual anchors to important information. You want your users to find your email and read what's inside. That empowers them and reduces your support load.

posts.html:
What’s the point of spending your time creating the perfect email if it’s not acted on? In this blog post we’ll dig into four tips on how to optimize your call to action.

Tip #1: Focus on the Subject Line

The subject line determines whether or not the email will be opened, read, and acted upon. A clear, concise, and to-the-point subject line is more likely to be opened than a lengthy or uninformative subject line. When writing transactional emails, it is essential to keep the subject line focused on the call to action. Including additional information or trying to be too clever can often backfire, resulting in the email being ignored or deleted. More on this here *subject line article.

Tip #2: Let’s Get Personal

Personalize your message as much as possible. A generic "Thanks for your purchase!" comes off as cold and impersonal. Take the time to write a message that sounds like it came from a friend, and you'll be much more likely to get the response you're looking for.

Tip #3: Get to the Point

The call to action should be prominently displayed and easy to find, and the overall message should be free of distractions. In addition, the email should be designed in a way that is both visually appealing and user-friendly. Let your customer get to the end goal quickly and easily.

Tip #4: A Thank You Goes a Long Way

You've written the perfect email, complete with a great offer and an enticing call to action. But there's one more important element to include before you hit send: a thank you. We're constantly bombarded with messages from all directions, show your customer that you appreciate them giving your message the time of day.

With a little tweaking and some careful thought about your customer’s needs, you can create transactional emails that not only get the job done, but also keep your customers happy. And happy customers are more likely to come back and buy from you again. What have you found to be the most effective call to action in your transactional emails? Let us know in the comments below!

posts.html:
Colors are powerful things. On the surface you probably think you learned all there was to know about colors by elementary school, but in reality they are much more complex. Especially when it comes to how they represent your brand.

Colors can evoke different emotions and thoughts in people, so it’s important to select the ones that resonate best with your customers if you want to most effectively convey your message - which is crucial for any successful transactional email! In this article we'll discuss how to choose the right colors for your brand.

What emotions do you want your brand to communicate?

There's a lot more than just great products and services that goes into building your brand. You also have to consider the emotions that the brand communicates.

For example, food brands that want their customers to feel clean, fresh, and healthy might consider using green as their primary color. This color evokes feelings of nature and vitality. Similarly, a luxury brand might use black or gold to communicate sophistication and elegance.

By carefully choosing colors that align with the desired emotions, brands can create a powerful and lasting impression on their customers.

What colors would create a positive association with the brand?

For example, bright colors = energy and excitement, while softer shades = relaxation and peace. Bright hues, pastels, and soft shades appeal to feminine demographics, while bold, rich, and undiluted colors are more masculine.

Different target audiences will respond differently to certain colors. Age, gender identity, culture, and economic status are all factors that should be considered when choosing colors for a brand.

Opposites Attract

Complementary colors are those that sit directly across from each other on the color wheel. The right color scheme can help to draw attention to key information and make it easier for recipients to process the email.

For example, blue's complementary color is orange, while red's is green. Using a blue background with orange text will help the text to stand out. Similarly, a green background with violet text can be used to create a sense of calmness and serenity.

Complementary colors provide a stark contrast to each other, making a design really pop. However, it's important to use them sparingly, too much of a contrast can be jarring. Instead, try using one or two as accent colors in an otherwise monochromatic design.

Shades, Tints, Tones & Hues

In the world of color, there are four basic terms used to describe different types of variations: hue, tint, tone, and shade. Let’s do some quick dictionary definitions incase you’re unfamiliar.

Hue - the purest form of a color, without any added white, black, or gray.

Tint - a hue to which white has been added, resulting in a lighter color.

Tone - a hue to which both black and white have been added, resulting in a color that is neither light nor dark.

Shade - a hue to which only black has been added, resulting in a darker color.

When choosing colors for your brand, consider all four of these variations in order to create a palette that is both visually appealing and reflective of your brand identity.

For example, if your brand is youthful and energetic, you might want to use brighter hues; if your brand is more mature and sophisticated, you might opt for richer shades.

How do you create a color palette that’s unique to your business?

A color palette is more than just a collection of pretty colors. It’s an essential part of your brand identity that allows for easy customer recognition. The right colors can convey the right message, create an emotional connection, and even boost sales.

The first step is to understand the meaning of colors and how they can be used to manipulate emotions.

For example, if you want to convey luxury and sophistication, you might choose rich jewel tones like ruby red or emerald green. If you want to convey energy and excitement, you might choose brighter shades like orange or yellow.

Once you know what emotions you want to convey, its important to take a peek into the competition. Look at other brands in your industry and see what colors they’re using. You don’t want to be too similar, but you also don’t want to be too different.

Color consistently creates a strong and recognizable brand identity. This means using the same or similar colors in all branding materials, from logos to website designs to product packaging. While it may seem like a small detail, consistent color usage can play a big role in helping customers remember and identify a brand.

For example, Google and Playstation both use multi-colored logos, but their tones, tints, and shades are always the same.

Transactional emails are a great opportunity to not only show off, but utilize your brand colors to your advantage. Choose colors that reflect your brand and help convey your message. What color combinations have you found work best for your brand? Let us know below!

While it can be tempting to use bright and colorful fonts in your transactional emails, using too much color can actually backfire. In this blog post, we'll share some tips for using color in your transactional emails so that they are both attractive and effective.

Create a Sense of Urgency

When used carefully, color can create a sense of urgency and encourage your customers to take action.

For example, red and yellow = excitement and vibrancy, making them ideal choices for transactional emails that seek to generate a sense of urgency.

Too much of one color can be off-putting and overwhelming, so use it sparingly.

Match your Brand

When customers see your colors in their inboxes, they’ll instantly recognize your brand and feel more confident opening your emails. You want your customers’ mind to automatically associate your brand with your colors. Using consistent colors across all of your communications will help do so. In the example below, DoorDash uses their brand's main color in this email to match the words that are the main focus of this email.

Eye-Catching & Easy on the Eyes

Like we talked about earlier, too much of any color can be overwhelming. Color should be used strategically so that your emails are not only readable, but also eye-catching. The best way to achieve this is by using a high contrast between the background and the text.

For example, if you have a light background, use dark text, and vice versa. You can also use color to highlight important information, such as CTAs or deadlines.

In this email from Overtone, a company that sells hair dye, they use their product to add a pop of color while leaving the rest of the email black and white, so the color truly stands out.

Make a Statement

While a consistent color palette is important for maintaining your brand's identity, there are times when using a different color can be effective.

For example, using a brighter or bolder version of your brand's color can help to emphasize important information. Alternatively, using a contrasting color can help to create visual interest and make key elements stand out. In the example below, Starbucks uses a lighter version of their brand's main color as a background, to make the words stand out.

Ultimately, choosing the right colors for transactional emails will depend on your goals and the overall tone of the message. However, don't be afraid to experiment with different shades and hues to see what works best for your audience.

Colors are an important part of any brand, and they can be especially powerful in transactional emails. Create a more positive experience for your customers and increase the likelihood that they will complete their purchase with the use of colors. Have you experimented with different colors in your transactional emails? What results did you see?

posts.html:
Step one to deciding on colors for your brand and emails, is to understand the psychology behind the colors. While every color can have both positive and negative connotations, it’s how they are crafted together with copy and imagery that leads to desired effects.

Red

Red is associated with excitement and passion. It is often used for sales, to warn of danger, and to show defiance. Red can be powerful as both a deterrent and to invoke intensity.

Studies have shown that athletes that go up against teams wearing red are more likely to lose, and students who are exposed to red before tests score lower than any other color. However, red, above all, inspires action.

Yellow

Yellow is the color of happiness and optimism. It invites warmth, cheerfulness, and enthusiasm.

Sale signs and road signs are commonly yellow and contrasted with dark text or symbols. The high contrast allows for attention-grabbing and capitalizing on impulsivity.

Green

Green is the color of nature and new beginnings. It sits in the middle of the color spectrum and invokes balance, calmness, and freshness.

Green is typically used in branding for holistic health, food, and financial wellness.

Blue

Blue is the symbolic opposite of red. Blue invokes calmness, serenity, and professionalism. Blue is also considered the most common favorite color in the world — possibly due to it being the color of the clear sky and water.

It’s a color good for expressing communication, reliability, and tradition.

Purple

Purple is considered a color of luxury and royalty for hundreds of years, as it’s a hard color to create from natural materials. However, purple is also associated with wisdom and mystery, and can be a powerful color for building excitement.

Black

Black is a common color to express independence, elegance, and seriousness.

Cars, electronics, and luxury brands commonly use the hue to show exclusivity. Black as a background color with lighter text can be easier for some eyes to read.

The psychology of colors and choosing the right colors for your brand can feel like a balancing act. Understanding the meaning behind the colors is a good first step to figuring it all out. What colors first come to mind for you that could be associated with your brand? Let us know below!

Blue is the symbolic opposite of red. Blue invokes calmness, serenity, and professionalism. Blue is also considered the most common favorite color in the world — possibly due to it being the color of the clear sky and water.

It’s a color good for expressing communication, reliability, and tradition.


Purple

Purple is considered a color of luxury and royalty for hundreds of years, as it’s a hard color to create from natural materials. However, purple is also associated with wisdom and mystery, and can be a powerful color for building excitement.


Black

Black is a common color to express independence, elegance, and seriousness.

Cars, electronics, and luxury brands commonly use the hue to show exclusivity. Black as a background color with lighter text can be easier for some eyes to read.

The psychology of colors and choosing the right colors for your brand can feel like a balancing act. Understanding the meaning behind the colors is a good first step to figuring it all out. What colors first come to mind for you that could be associated with your brand? Let us know below!

posts.html:
There's no denying that color plays a big role in our lives. It can affect our moods, our emotions, and even our behavior. And when it comes to transactional emails, color can be just as important. After all, you want your email to stand out in a crowded inbox and get noticed by your recipients. But how do you know which colors to use? Here are a few tips to help you get started:

1: Consider the meaning of different colors. Understanding the psychology of colors can be helpful in choosing the right tones for your message. For example, red is often associated with excitement or urgency, while blue is often seen as calming and serene. When choosing colors for your email, think about the message you want to convey and choose colors that will support that message.

The Emotions of Color

2: Keep in mind that less is sometimes more. When it comes to using color in transactional emails, it's important to remember that less is often more. Avoid using too many colors in your email as this can be overwhelming for subscribers and make it difficult for them to focus on the desired call-to-action. Stick with one or two complementary colors to create a visually pleasing and effective email campaign.

Tips for Using Color in Transactional Emails

3: You want to make sure that the color you choose represents your brand. If you're a fun and funky brand, then you'll want to choose colors that reflect that likely with bright and bold colors. However, if you're a more serious and professional brand, then you'll probably want more subtle and neutral colors.

Choosing Colors for your Brand

If you're interested in learning more on any of these topics, we dive in depth on each of them in separate blog posts linked above. Enveloop's templates make it super simple to implement these tips in your emails. Check it out!

posts.html:
When it comes to email subject lines, emojis can be your best friend.

In a world where we are constantly bombarded with emails, it can be hard to stand out from the crowd. But using an emoji in your subject line is a great way to grab attention and increase engagement. After all, who doesn't love a little bit of color and fun? Emojis are eye-catching, and they can convey emotions that words alone cannot. Plus, they can help to set the tone for your email, whether you're trying to be funny or friendly. So if you're looking to add a little personality to your transactional emails, consider using an emoji in your subject line.

Do: Stay Relevant

Relevance is key when it comes to using emojis in transactional email subject lines. You want to make sure that the emoji you use is relevant to the email content and will resonate with your audience. In addition, it's important to keep things fresh by using different emojis in your subject lines from time to time. This will help keep your emails top of mind and ensure that your subscribers open them. So have fun with it and experiment with different emojis!

Don't: Be Inappropriate

Emojis may be casual, but they shouldn't be used in an offensive or insensitive way. Just remember to use them sparingly and to avoid anything that could be construed as inappropriate. Sometimes something you mean innocently could be interpreted in an offensive way, so make sure you think twice and have someone look it over first to make sure you're not missing anything. Stick to emojis that convey professionalism, respectfulness, and sincerity.

Do: Keep it Clean

Less is more. A couple of carefully chosen emojis can be effective, but a string of them can come across as try-hard or even juvenile.

Don't: Overdo it

Used judiciously, emojis can be a fun way to add some personality to your transactional emails. But it's important to use them sparingly. Try to limit yourself to one or two emojis per subject line - too many can come across as unprofessional or spammy.

Do: Convey the Tone

Make sure they fit the tone of your message. If you're sending a serious email about a financial transaction, for example, using lighthearted emojis may not be appropriate. A winky face might be cute in a casual email to a friend, but it's probably not the best choice for a confirmation email from your bank.

Don't: Be Ignorant of Browsers and Updates

Be cautious of browsers that can't load some emojis. Not all browsers and phone softwares are created equal when it comes to emoji support. This may result in your emojis showing up as question marks in boxes like in the example below. So if you're going to use emojis in your email subject lines, make sure to test them out in a few different browsers and phones first to make sure they display properly.

Just remember to keep it relevant and appropriate for your audience. And if you're not sure which emoji to use, there's always the trusty old smiley face!

posts.html:
I know, I know. You're thinking to yourself, "Another blog post about GIFs? Do we really need another one of those?" And my answer to you is yes. Yes, we do. Because when it comes to making transactional emails more engaging - particularly those automated "thank you" messages that everyone seems to send these days - GIFs are the way to go.

OK, so maybe that wasn't the most earth shattering piece of information you've ever heard, but trust me, it's worth paying attention to. Especially if you're looking for ways to cut through the noise and stand out from the competition. So without further ado, let’s first explain what a GIF is.

So, what are GIFs?

GIFs are a series of photos or soundless videos that play on a loop. They don’t require anyone to press play or pause, so they’ll continue to run without any intervention. While some companies use GIFs from popular shows/movies/etc. or random clips like the ones in this post, others will incorporate it into the design of the email so one aspect of an otherwise two dimensional email, will have automation. This one might explain how you're feeling right now, but don't worry we're here to help!

Six reasons why you should consider adding GIFs to your transactional emails:

  1. GIFs are eye-catching and attention grabbing
  2. They create a sense of community and social connection
  3. They can add levity and humor to an otherwise mundane message
  4. They help break up text-heavy emails and make them more visually appealing
  5. They're a great way to show off your brand's personality
  6. Like emojis, they can be used to express distinct emotions that wouldn’t be portrayed through text alone.

Differentiate Your Brand

GIFs are a great way to show off your personality and help your brand stand out from the competition. Especially when doing business in the B2B space, it’s easy for brands to come off as unapproachable and boring, so GIFs can help add some personality to transactional emails. Differentiate yourself and express your brand’s voice.

Don’t Overdo It

Too much of a good thing can take away from the benefits they bring. Adding too many GIFs to your email might come across as unprofessional. Overdoing it can also be distracting and overwhelming. Make sure to keep it to a minimum and only add a GIF where you feel it adds value to the message, or else you'll leave your customers feeling like this...

Need to be Supported

GIFs are a great addition to an email, but an empty box with a question mark is not. While most internet browsers today do support GIFs, there are still some that do not. It's important to be cognizant of making sure most, if not all, of your customers are able to see your email the way you intended.

So what are you waiting for? Start using GIFs in your transactional emails and see how much more engaging they become. Not sure where to find gifs that would be appropriate for your business or industry? Check out Giphy (giphy.com) or Tenor (tenor.com). They’re both great resources for finding the perfect GIF for any occasion. Have you tried using GIFs in your transactional emails yet? If not, what’s stopping you?

posts.html:
While text is all you really need in an email, it’s not going to set you apart. Emojis and GIFs are easy ways to showcase your brand’s identity and improve the performance of your transactional emails.

Sounds pretty simple, right⁉️​ Throw in an emoji or two. Doing so without being strategic and thoughtful might just backfire on you. These are a few do's and don'ts to help you avoid that.

Don’t: Overuse Emojis and GIFs

When used wisely, emojis and GIFs can help add some personality to your transactional emails and make them more engaging. You don’t want to overdo it though. Too many can take away from the message you’re trying to convey 😵‍💫.​

Do: Use Emojis & GIFs for Clarity & Personality

Stick to a few well-chosen emojis or gifs that help improve the clarity of your email and showcase the personality of your brand. Not being cautious of this could result in coming across as too casual or unprofessional, or even get your emails flagged as spam.

Don't: Only Focus on the Emojis & GIFs

It's important to remember that the emojis or GIFs should never be used at the expense of high-quality content. Otherwise you risk coming across as unprofessional or just plain lazy.

Do: Have Strong & Compelling Content

The best transactional emails will always have strong copy and compelling content, with emojis and gifs serving as added visual elements to help capture attention ​📣​ and drive engagement 📈​.

Don't: Add Emojis & GIFs Without a Purpose

Using these graphics in your email can be impactful to the message, but if they don't correlate it just makes your customer confused. If you don't think the Emoji or GIF add value to the message, you shouldn't use it. If it does connect with the email's purpose, you still have to make sure its' placement is fitting.

Do: Know Where to Add Emojis and GIFs

Where do you place the emoji or GIF for the most impact? Many businesses will add emojis into the subject lines, and also scatter them throughout the body copy. However, when it comes to GIFs, they cannot be added into the email subject line. Instead, add one or two GIFs in the body copy when appropriate. Use them sparingly and only when they genuinely add to the email content.

When used well, emojis and GIFs can help to add a touch of personality to transactional emails and make them more engaging for recipients. So, what are you waiting for? Go ahead and try out these tips to see how they can help improve your transactional email performance.

posts.html:
Think about the last time you received an email from a company. More likely than not, it was a transactional email—an automated message confirming your purchase or shipping information, for example. Though they're important for keeping customers informed, these types of messages can often be dry and unengaging.

Enter: Emojis and GIFs. Making your emails more engaging and interesting has never been easier. While quick and effective, throwing in some random emojis and GIFs into your emails won't do the trick. Make sure you are being smart and strategic.

Here are some tips.

1: GIFs are the perfect way to add some personality to your transactional emails. They're eye-catching, visually appealing, and can express a wide range of emotions that text alone simply can't convey. Not to mention, they're just plain fun!

How to Make Transactional Emails More Engaging: Using GIFs

2: Emojis can be a great way to add personality to your transactional emails, but there are a few things to keep in mind. First, try to use them sparingly - too many emoji can come across as unprofessional. Second, make sure they genuinely add value to your message - no one wants to be bombarded with irrelevant pictures. And finally, don't be afraid to experiment - we're all still learning the best way to use these little pictograms. So have fun, and see what works best for you and your audience.

Using Emojis in Transactional Emails

3: When it comes to using emojis in your subject lines, theres a few things to consider. First, it's important to stay relevant - that is, only use an emoji if it makes sense in the context of the message. Otherwise, it could come across as being inappropriate or even insensitive. Second, keep it clean - that is, avoid using emojis that might be construed as offensive or inappropriate for a business setting. And third, don't overdo it - too many emojis in an email can be just as confusing as none at all.

Do's and Don'ts of Using Emojis in Your Subject Line

4: Emojis and GIFs can be a great way to add some personality to an otherwise boring email. Just make sure you don't overdo it! A few well-placed emojis can go a long way. And if you're going to use gifs, make sure they are high quality and relevant to your brand. Otherwise, you run the risk of coming across as try-hard or tone deaf. Knowing where to add emojis and gifs is also important.

Do's and Don'ts of Using Emojis and GIFs in Transactional Emails

Using emojis and GIFs in your transactional emails can help you to show a more human side to your brand, increase customer engagement, and boost conversion rates. Have you tried using them in your own transactional emails? What results did you see? Let us know in the comments!

Enveloop is a developer-focused message builder and API that makes it easy to design & send beautiful emails and texts from your app using one simple implementation. You can sign up for free at: https://app.enveloop.com.

You open your email and see a new message. Did you order something online or ask to reset your password? Or is it your favorite store promoting their upcoming product release. These two different types of emails can be categorized as transactional emails or marketing emails. While to the customer, the difference might not be so obvious but when we bring it back to the creation of the email, a company views these very differently. Let's take a look a few ways we can differentiate these two types and some of the pros and cons of both.

Marketing Emails

The first type of email is the marketing email. Marketing emails are typically sent on a regular schedule (weekly, bi-weekly, monthly, etc.) and contain general information about the company, such as new products or sales. They usually don't require any action from the customer other than reading and perhaps clicking through to the company's website.

Pros:
• Can be sent on a regular schedule, which can be helpful for building brand awareness and keeping your company top-of-mind for potential customers.
• Can be less expensive and time-consuming to create than triggered emails since they don't require segments or personalized content.

Cons:
• Because they're not personalized, they can come across as impersonal and even spammy. This can lead to customers unsubscribing from your email list or marking your messages as "junk."
• There's no guarantee that customers will actually read your marketing emails since they usually don't require any immediate action. In fact, many people simply delete them without even opening them.

Transactional Emails

The second type of email is the transactional email, also known as triggered emails. Transactional emails are sent in response to a specific action that a customer takes (or doesn't take), such as abandoning their shopping cart or signing up for a free trial. They usually contain personalized content that is relevant to the customer's interests or needs.

Pros:
• Because they're personalized and relevant, triggered emails generally have higher open and click-through rates than marketing emails. This means that your message is more likely to be seen and acted upon by your audience.
• They can create a sense of urgency or importance that encourages customers to take action immediately.
• They can be automated using software like Enveloop, which makes them less time-consuming and expensive to create than marketing emails.

Cons:

• Triggering an email too often can annoy your customers and lead to them unsubscribing from your list or marking your messages as "junk."  For example, sending a 'Welcome!' email when someone first signs up for your newsletter is fine, but sending them another one every day for the next week is probably overkill.   Timing is everything with triggered emails!

• While triggered emails are very effective, they do require some initial work to set up tracking systems and determine what actions will trigger an email. This can be time-consuming upfront. Although that's where Enveloop comes in, by taking out the time consuming part out of getting started and keeping up with it.

So, which type of email is better? The answer probably depends on your goals and objectives. If you're just looking to build brand awareness or keep your company top-of-mind for potential customers, then marketing emails might be a good option for you. However, if you're looking to increase sales or encourage customers to take action, then triggered emails are probably a better bet. As with anything else in business, it's all about finding what works best for you and your audience!

posts.title: Welcome to Enveloop!
posts.html:
Hey there, we're Enveloop – a developer-focused message builder and API that makes it easy to design & send emails and texts from your app using one simple call.

Enveloop enables you, as a developer, to design, test, and deliver messages to different places using different formats.

Why we built Enveloop

Developers create apps. These apps, well, need to talk to users. Simple, right?

Unfortunately — multiple APIs, maintaining message content, design standards, delivery standards, handling failure/retry -- you have to figure it all out and, over time, it all becomes scattered in your code.

Worse — it’s inaccessible to those that need to edit the messaging because the design & content is buried in your code with all the implementation details — as a developer, that puts you in the middle of any update, big or small. Gross.

We’ve built a service that solves user messaging. It’s simple for developers, collaborative for consultants and their clients, and ready for fast-moving product & development teams. It’s Enveloop.

What Enveloop Offers

  • A powerful but simple-to-use message builder.
  • Intuitive formatting optimized for developers. (Support for Markdown & Mustache)
  • Elegant templates that allow you to get started fast without needing a designer.
  • Delegation of content messaging to others on your team (or to your clients!).
  • A single API that supports multiple message types and providers.
  • Integration with multiple delivery platforms (SendGrid, Mailgun, AWS SES).

Just Getting Started

Along with our powerful editor, we include many message integrations. We have plans for more great features, including more integrations, message types, workflows, and useful analytics. We'll keep you posted!

Try Enveloop Out!

Everything we've done is focused on creating a service that helps developers reduce complexity and reduce unneeded deployments. We'd love to have you try Enveloop out. You get 10,000 messages free per month!

We're happy to grab a few mins to help you set everything up. Reach out to founders@enveloop.com!

The Enveloop Team

posts.title: Enveloop Templates
posts.html:
Enveloop is a developer-focused message builder and API that makes it easy to design & send beautiful emails and texts from your app using one simple implementation. You can sign up for free at: https://app.enveloop.com.

Ok, so let's talk templates. A bit of a boring word, but it's the powerful core of Enveloop. Templates (or Message Templates) are the top-level containers for your content, design, and dynamic content. Each template represents a type of message you need to send. For example:

  • User Invited
  • User Welcome
  • Forgot Password
  • New Team Created

Templates are the building blocks of the transactional message platform you can create on top of Enveloop. You can add as many as you need. Templates give you a lot of power & control and, in our coming blog posts, we'll talk more about how to take advantage.

In this article, we'll cover the basics of what a template is. The easiest way to do this in Enveloop is to use one of the options from our Template Gallery. Select a style, color, and name of your template and you're ready to go. You can also start with a blank template.

Template Modes

After creating a new template, you'll enter into the Build mode.

Build Mode

When working with Enveloop templates, this is where you'll spend most of your time and where you can edit your content and design. Click on different parts of the message to start editing. Also, in the right drawer, styling options are available for fonts, colors, spacing, and layout.

Test Mode

After creating a template, switching to Test mode allows you to see an in-browser preview of your message. Also, you can quickly send an actual test message to your inbox to preview your message in your personal inbox / mail client.

Also important to note, in this mode, the right drawer in the UI has become a place to enter test data for any variables you included in your message template. This is a great way to preview how dynamic content, from your app, will render in your messages.

Want to see how your message looks in mobile? Enveloop makes this easy with the view window selector located at the bottom of the screen.

Deploy Mode

Once you are satisfied with your message, Deploy mode provides you with language-specific code to embed the necessary API call in your app. You can also cURL a message from a local terminal window.

Still More to Cover!

There's plenty of additional detail to cover about message templates – We'll do this in future articles – including: elements, sections, and saved sections.

posts.title: Designing Messages in Enveloop
posts.html:
Enveloop is a developer-focused message builder and API that makes it easy to design & send beautiful emails and texts from your app using one simple implementation. You can sign up for free at: https://app.enveloop.com.

We've talked about Enveloop Templates (or Message Templates) and described how templates act as the top-level containers for all the content you want to include in a message. In this article, we're going to build on this and talk about how you can easily add layout and design to your content.

Enveloop Message Builder

Enveloop's Message Builder is the heart of our service, allowing developers to effortlessly build out transactional messages that would normally be coded inside your app. You can create both text-only (SMS, MMS) messages as well as messages that support design elements — email for now, but more coming soon!

Instead of having to code HTML & CSS and test for numerous mail clients, Enveloop gives you all this control with a friendly UI and provides you confidence that your messages will display correctly to your end users.

Let's dive into how to create beautiful messages in Enveloop!

A Quick Reminder

If you're unfamiliar with the structure of message templates, we've written some articles and have some great docs that offer a more detailed view. As a brief reminder, Enveloop messages are structured this way:

flowchart TB id1([Template]) --> id2([Sections]) --> id3([Elements])

A Template acts as a container for your content. Sections represent groups of content and can also have layouts (single vs. multi-column) associated with them, like headers and footers. Elements are specific types of content: text, buttons, images, etc.

When you are sending email messages with Enveloop, each of these message components have styling options you can use. Let's briefly learn about each and its capabilities.

💡
If you're just getting started with Enveloop, a great way to see all the design capabilities of Enveloop is to create a template with one of the designs from our template gallery.

Template Styles

Templates hold all the content of your messages. Think of them as the outer structure of, for example, an email you want to send (like a "Forgot Password" email).

Templates have style properties. Since they hold the content of your messages, the values any styles you define here (colors, fonts, etc.) can be inherited by the content that you put inside your template.

A simple illustration: If, in your Template Style tab, you set text color to be dark gray, the text of any content you place inside your template, including sections and elements, will automatically inherit that color – unless you define a different color for that content in the Section and Element styles. We'll discuss that in a moment!

You can view and modify template styles by clicking the outside of the message and choosing the "Template Styles" tab.

Section Styles

Any content you want to add to a template will be contained in a section. Sections have styles, too. When you click on a section in the message, you have a couple of options: Layout and Section Style.

Section styles, like template styles, allow you to control colors, fonts, and padding.

Element Styles

Along with the content that you can place in sections, you can include additional Elements that are useful in crafting messages. These include:

  • Text
  • Image
  • Button
  • Heading
  • Divider

Each of these elements has style options as well -- according to its use. A button, for example, includes colors, sizing, and structure (rounded, square, etc.)

How it All Connects

Understanding the hierarchy of elements (inside of) sections (inside of) templates allows you to understand how each type inherits from the other. This provides you both the level of specificity that you need as well as more powerful global control of the design of your message.

Markdown, too!

One final note: Along with the UI that Enveloop provides to you to control your design, don't forget about the use of Markdown for added formatting of text. This includes support for headings, paragraphs, links, emphasis, blockquotes, lists, etc. We discuss this in greater detail in Enveloop Docs for Markdown.

Try it Out!

Enveloop is free to get started and you can build out and send you first template in under 5 minutes! Storing all your message code, design, and provider integrations in your app is an anti-pattern. Enveloop helps you send better messages and allows you to easily delegate messaging to others on your team!

Happy Sending! 🚀
